channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘The Storm of Reality’: Chinese Poetic Voices From the Lower Tier of Society
item.description: Reacting to a far more complicated, and in some ways tougher, reality than when a last wave of poetry caught public attention in the 1980s, new voices are emerging from China’s working class.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Shangguan Nanhua, with his family in Beijing at the poetry awards, where he won first prize for his anthology "Eights Beats of the Ganzhou Song."

item.title: BelÉm Journal: Daring Fare, From the Amazon’s Mouth to Yours
item.description: A Brazilian chef who passed up the glamour of São Paulo is helping change his country’s cuisine with the help of flavors from the rain forest.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Assassination in Tunisia Draws Spouse Into Politics
item.description: Mbarka Brahmi is campaigning for the seat of her husband, Mohamed Brahmi, the left-wing politician whose assassination by an Islamist extremist group last year sent Tunisia into a crisis.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Oil Gives Kurds a Path to Independence, and Conflict With Baghdad
item.description: Kurdish officials are desperately trying to sell oil abroad, even as the Iraqi government and the United States are blocking their attempts.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Chen Ziming, Dissident in China, Is Dead at 62
item.description: A reform-minded intellectual, Mr. Chen, was accused by the government of fomenting the Tiananmen Square protests in 1989 and spent more than a decade in prison and under house arrest.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER
item.media:description: Chen Ziming in 1995. Mr. Chen spent more than a decade in prison and under house arrest for his reformist activities.

item.title: ISIS Hostages Endured Torture and Dashed Hopes, Freed Cellmates Say
item.description: The death of James Foley in August at the hands of Islamic State jihadists in Syria was a very public end to a hidden ordeal shared with nearly two dozen other Westerners.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Jasper Juinen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The father of Jejoen Bontinck, a young Belgian who spent three weeks in the same cell as James Foley and other hostages, showed a picture of the prison where they were held.

item.title: As Brazil’s Presidential Race Draws to Close, Voters Lament Its Ugliness
item.description: Many Brazilians have been stunned by what may be the country’s most contentious election since the end of military rule.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Negro? Prieto? Moreno? A Question of Identity for Black Mexicans
item.description: Mexico is planning to do something it has not attempted in decades and never on its modern census: ask people if they consider themselves black.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: More Than 10,000 Africa Ebola Cases, Health Agency Says
item.description: A total of 10,141 people had contracted the disease worldwide, the World Health Organization said in its latest update on the progress of the epidemic.
item.dc:creator: By NICK BRUCE

item.title: Aid Is In, but Gazans Can Only Look at Supplies
item.description: Reconstruction of homes damaged or destroyed in this summer’s battle between Israel and Hamas remains distant, as supplies allowed into Gaza this month remain untouched, baffling residents.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hatem Shammaly at a warehouse with building supplies. Many Gazans are not getting the materials needed to make repairs.

item.title: Parliamentary Elections Show Political Turmoil Is Continuing in Ukraine
item.description: The vote on Sunday was envisioned as a final step in transforming government from a kleptocracy to a reform-minded administration, but infighting and charges of corruption suggest the transformation may take longer.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Election workers prepared ballots in Kramatorsk, a town in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Coalition Seeks to Send North Korea to International Court Over Rights Abuses
item.description: Seven months after a groundbreaking report documenting torture and starvation in North Korea, a broad coalition of countries is pushing to refer Pyongyang to the International Criminal Court.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: At the United Nations last week, Kim Song, center, of the North Korean mission, said reports of human rights abuses in his country were a Western plot.

item.title: Afghan Mullah Who Raped Girl in His Mosque Receives 20-Year Prison Sentence
item.description: Women’s activists attending the packed proceedings hailed it as a victory because the mullah was successfully prosecuted under a 2009 law meant to fight violence against women.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassina Sarwari, who runs a Kunduz shelter, with a photo of the girl who was raped by a mullah.

item.title: Rights Groups Condemn Execution of Iranian Woman
item.description: The execution of a woman in Iran who killed a doctor she said had tried to rape her was carried out Saturday despite international condemnation.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Reyhaneh Jabbari, shown in Tehran in 2008, was hanged on Saturday. She had been convicted of murdering a doctor she said had tried to rape her.

item.title: News Analysis: Attacks in West Raise New Fears Over ISIS’ Influence
item.description: Analysts say the far-flung plots and attacks are a change in the nature of the group and its threat to the West.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Ottawa Gunman’s Radicalism Deepened as Life Crumbled
item.description: Michael Zehaf-Bibeau was troubled and unstable, and he initially may have sought religion as an attempt to scaffold a disintegrating life.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WINES and WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: An image taken from social media of Michael Zehaf-Bibeau.

item.title: Ghulam Azam, Party Leader Jailed in Bangladesh War Crime, Dies at 91
item.description: A former chief of the Jamaat-e-Islami Party, Mr. Azam’s imprisonment on war crimes charges linked to the 1971 Bangladesh war of independence from Pakistan set off violent protests last year.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: E.U. Greenhouse Gas Deal Falls Short of Expectations
item.description: The varied energy needs and capacity of member nations led to concessions and compromises that experts say watered down an agreement meant to pressure other countries at climate talks in 2015.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: European Union leaders and family members in Brussels on Thursday. Their accord aimed to set the stage for talks next year.

item.title: In French Port City, ‘a Real Psychosis’
item.description: Resentment and fear have swept Calais, France, in the last year amid a new wave of migrants hoping to cross illegally to Britain, which they see as a better place than France to start a new life.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Israeli Troops Kill Palestinian Teenager in the West Bank, the 2nd in 8 Days
item.description: The Israeli military said the youth had thrown a firebomb onto a main road often used by settlers.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sunni Militants Draw Iraqi Forces Into Intense Battles on Several Fronts
item.description: Government forces fought for the third straight day to fend off a heavy assault by Islamic State militants on a strategically placed town in Anbar Province.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: U.S. Commander Sees Key Nuclear Step by North Korea
item.description: Gen. Curtis M. Scaparrotti, the top American military leader in South Korea, says he believes the North is capable of making a nuclear weapon small enough to fit atop a ballistic missile.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Mali Reports First Death From Ebola
item.description: The death of a 2-year-old girl who traveled across two countries while showing symptoms of Ebola is the first recorded Ebola death in Mali.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Open Source: Iranian Photojournalist Reportedly Detained After Covering Protest Against Acid Attacks
item.description: Arya Jafari was reported to have been detained over his images of protesters deploring acid attacks on women in Isfahan.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Thousands of Iranians attended a protest on Wednesday in the city of Isfahan to demand justice for women disfigured in a spate of acid attacks.

item.title: Islamist Party in Tunisia Appears Set to Rebound
item.description: After ceding power to a caretaker government in January, Ennahda enters Sunday’s national legislative elections as a front-runner.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Supporters of Rachid Ghannouchi, the founder and head of the Ennahda party, at a campaign rally this week in Slimania, Tunisia.
